div.l: In to som worthi blood of Auncetrie
For holi chirche good mot be dispended
On holi chirche blood that is descended
Therfor he wolde his holi blood honoure
Thouȝ that he holi chirche shuld deuoure
Gret soken had the Millere out of doute
With whete and malt of al the lond aboute
And nameli there was a gret Collage
Men clepe it the Soler halle at Cambrigge
There was here whete and eke here malt I grounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Seke lay the manciple on a maladie
Men wenden wiseli that he shuld die
For wich this Millere stal bothe mele ⁊and corn̄
An C· tyme than he did beforn
For there before he took ful curteisli
But now he was a thef outrageously
For wich the wardein chid and fare
But therof set nat the Millere atare
He crakes bost and swore it was nat so
Than were there yong poore scolers tuo
That haden duelled in the halle of wich I sey
Testif they were and lusti for to pley
And onli for her mirthe and reuelrie
Vpon the wardein besili they crie
To yeue hem leue but a litill stounde
To go to the mille and se her corn grounde
And hardeli thei durst ley her necke
The Millere shuld nat stele hem half a pecke
Of corn · be sleiȝte ne be force hem reue
And ate last the wardein iaf hem leue
Iohn hiȝt that oon and Aleyn hiȝt that other
Of oo toun were they born that hiȝt Strother
Fer in the north I can nat telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
And on an hors the sak he cast anon
Forth goth Alein the clerk and also Iohn
With good swerd and bokeler be her side
Iohn knewe the wey hem neded no guide
And at the last the sak doun he leith
Alein spak first al heill Simond in feith
Hou fares thi faire douȝter and thi wif
